Richard, Gordon and All,

I finally took more pictures of this Tsuba. The pic's are the first
seven in my photo album. The photo's aren't the best, I am still an
amateur at taking photo's. Hope they help you solve the
identification of this Tsuba.

Thanks as always,

Elliott

Richard,

The only un-mounted picture of this tsuba is now in my Photo Album.
The sword is in-route to me as I speak. As soon as I get it, I will

If the one picture works for you as I hope it does, great. If not, I
should have the sword by this weekend. More pic's forth coming.

Thanks for your help,

Elliott

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Elliott
Sent: Wednesday, May 23, 2007 12:13 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Tsuba ID



I am back! With another question. I own a sword that has a mei of Soshu
Ju Hiromasa. It is papered by NBTHK as Hozon attributing this mei as
correct. I have researched the Zuikan, Jiten and Fujishiro and believe
it is a correct signature and probably the fifth Hiromasa.

The question is, who made the Tsuba? Is it Kyo-sukashi or Akasaka? Or
is it something else? Please see my photo album for the pictures I have
of it. All the pic's show it mounted.

Thank you as always,

Elliott





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba ID
messages.msgSnippet: Hi John, thanks for those comments, yes it s pretty rustic, LOL, good word that, it covers sooo much. My description should have said 2.3mm thick. Wow, 1.3 mm
messages.messageBody:
Hi John, thanks for those comments, yes it's pretty rustic, LOL, good
word that, it covers sooo much. My description should have said 2.3mm
thick. Wow, 1.3 mm would be a very thin tsuba, more decorative that
practical ????. I don't think there are any bones, I need to take better
pics, when the sun returns I will attempt it. I am also curious about
the wheel motif, if it is ?, all the wheel tsuba I have are either
round, or a round wheel in another shape, but the wheel itself is always
round. I wonder if this is something else I cannot see.

Rich

John Berta wrote:

> Hi Rich;
>
> Very interesting tsuba. I do not think I have ever seen one like it.
> Not the design or the unusually shaped large kozuka hitsu. Sort of
> like some of the early Jingo but different.
>
> The shape of the nakago ana is also unusual in that it does not have
> the shape you would expect to see that would tightly fit a nakago, and
> I think it would be difficult to fit a seppa without covering the
> sukashi design.
>
> The look of the iron on the plate seems a little coarser and I do not
> see any of the large bones in the surface of the plate. Its hard to
> tell from pictures though. The hoan tsuba I have handled have been
> abut 1.2 to 1.3mm thick.
>
> Very interesting unusual tsuba.
>
> John

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba ID
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich; Very interesting tsuba.  I do not think I have ever seen one like it.  Not the design or the unusually shaped large kozuka hitsu.  Sort of like some
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich;

Very interesting tsuba. I do not think I have ever seen one like it. Not the design or the unusually shaped large kozuka hitsu. Sort of like some of the early Jingo but different.

The shape of the nakago ana is also unusual in that it does not have the shape you would expect to see that would tightly fit a nakago, and I think it would be difficult to fit a seppa without covering the sukashi design.

The look of the iron on the plate seems a little coarser and I do not see any of the large bones in the surface of the plate. Its hard to tell from pictures though. The hoan tsuba I have handled have been abut 1.2 to 1.3mm thick.

Very interesting unusual tsuba.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, June 25, 2003 5:18 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Tsuba ID


Greeting all, I have added some pics to my site, see here

http://www.whiz.com.au/richard/Sukashi%20Wheel%20Tsuba.htm

and am curious as to thoughts on this piece. It is signed but very hard
to read, I think Yoshi ??? but not sure. It was bought as Hôan school,
momoyama period but I am unsure of that also. I don't think it is that
old but again I could be wrong. it is 73 mm wide x 77 mm high and 2.5 mm
and has a nice feel and look to it.

any thought's as to school, age etc. would be greatly appreciated.

cheers

Rich
